Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The nun has a quiet afternoon and plans to spend time in personal spiritual reading and contemplation.
Story: I sat in my small room at the convent, sunlight filtering through the window, my Bible open on my lap. The quiet of the afternoon was perfect for reflection, and I had been looking forward to this time all week. Just as I began to read, my phone buzzed. It was a message from my mother: “Can we talk? Dad seems down lately.” My heart tightened. As a daughter, I knew how much my parents relied on me for comfort, especially now that I lived away from home. They expected me to check in, to listen, to reassure them that everything would be alright. But as a nun, I was called to set aside worldly concerns, to focus on spiritual growth and contemplation, especially during these precious moments of solitude. I stared at the phone, torn between the gentle pull of my family’s needs and the quiet call of my faith. The silence in the room grew heavy, and I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding a part of me I wasn’t sure I could give.
